results.title: The Clock
results.brief_description: The Clock is a 24-hour video installation created from thousands of clips of clocks, watches and other references to time from film and television.

results.description:
The Clock is a 24-hour video installation created from thousands of clips of clocks, watches and other references to time from film and television. These are masterfully edited together and synced to the present moment in one mesmerising collage. The result is an epic journey through cinematic history as well as a functioning timepiece.

Minute by minute, hour by hour, hundreds of characters are jolted awake by alarms, run for trains, wait for lovers, or dream strange dreams. Stitched together from hours of cinematic history, The Clock gifts audiences the addictive joy of recognising favourite actors or scenes from beloved films, as well as being wildly compelling and dream-like itself.

Since debuting in 2010, The Clock has become one of the most seen and celebrated artworks of our time, winning the Golden Lion at the 2011 Venice Biennale, and attracting critical acclaim and enthusiastic audiences at gallery showings across the world.

results.title: The Clinic
results.creator_credit: David Stevens, Bob Weis, Robert Le Tet, Generation Films and The Film House
results.brief_description: Take an innocent intern on his first day at a VD clinic, add in a bunch of doctors and nurses who have seen it all before then mix it all up with the craziest and funniest patients you’ll ever meet. That’s the recipe for this highly infectious comedy. Stars Chris Haywood and Simon Burke.

results.title: The Climate puzzle
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Planet earth”.
Scientists tell us that no human beings have ever experienced the earth’s “normal climate”. Civilisation has flourished in a narrow window between vast ice ages. When will climate change again and why? Are we entering a new ice age, or will the current global warming trend from the greenhouse effect, hold off the inevitable?

results.title: The Client
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Steven Reuther, Arnon Milchan, Warner Bros Pictures and Monarchy Enterprises B. V.
results.brief_description: Mark Sway, an 11 year old trailer park kid (Brad Renfro) witnesses the suicide of a Mafia lawyer, who confesses that the Mob was behind the murder of a U.S. senator. Mark’s brother is traumatized into a coma by the incident and soon Mark finds himself torn between what he knows and what he can never tell. Gangster Barry Muldano (Anthony LaPaglia) is on Mark’s trail, and in desperation Mark arrives at the office of recovering alcoholic lawyer Reggie Love (Susan Sarandon). With the Mob after them, and a ruthless federal attorney (Tommy Lee Jones) trying to force Mark to reveal what he knows, Love battles to guarantee the safety of her client and his family. Based on the novel by John Grisham. Music by Howard Shore.

results.title: The Clerk
results.creator_credit: Allan Wargon, Morten Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nature of Work”.
This film explores the conflict between what a man (in this case an office clerk) wants from his job and what the company wants from him. It raises the question of how far an industry ought to be expected to go in relieving dull, repetitive work for the sake of employee satisfaction.

results.title: The Cleo Laine collection
results.creator_credit: Graeme Rowland, Bill Ramsey and de Montignie Productions
results.brief_description: Recorded live at the Melbourne Concert Hall in 1986, this video presents the sensuous and sultry jazz and blues singer Cleo Laine performing with her husband John Dankworth and the Dankworth Quartet. British born Cleo Laine began her musical career in the early 1950s where she met and married renowned musician John Dankworth in 1958. Together they have toured the world (and still currently touring) but Cleo has also tried her hand at acting on the stage in such plays as “Flesh to a tiger”, “A Midsummer night’s dream” and the title role in Ibsen’s “Hedda Gabler” among many other performances. Songs from this Melbourne concert by this great lady include “Free and easy”, “I love you just the way you are”, “Crazy rhythm”, “Send in the clowns”, “He was beautiful”.
